questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer from a rural village in Southeast Asia presents to the clinic with complaints of painful black discoloration and ulcerations on his toes and feet. He reports that his symptoms began gradually and have worsened over the past few months. His medical history is unremarkable, but he mentions that he has been drinking well water from his local area for many years. Physical examination reveals signs of peripheral vascular insufficiency, with necrotic patches on his lower extremities suggestive of gangrene. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Arsenic poisoning, particularly due to chronic exposure through contaminated drinking water, is known to cause a condition called Blackfoot disease, an endemic peripheral vascular disease predominantly seen in specific regions such as the southwest coast of Taiwan. Chronic arsenic exposure leads to peripheral vascular damage, resulting in ischemia and gangrene of the lower extremities, which manifests as black discoloration of the feet, hence the name "Blackfoot." This condition is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease caused by long-term ingestion of arsenic-laden water, leading to progressive tissue necrosis and ulceration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Thallium poisoning: Thallium poisoning can cause a range of symptoms, including hair loss, gastrointestinal disturbances, and neurological deficits. However, it does not specifically lead to peripheral gangrene or the characteristic black discoloration of the feet seen in Blackfoot disease.
  • • A. Thallium poisoning:
  • • B. Cadmium poisoning: Cadmium poisoning is primarily associated with renal damage, bone demineralization, and respiratory complications, especially from inhalation exposure. It does not cause peripheral vascular disease or gangrenous changes like those seen in arsenic-related Blackfoot disease.
  • • B. Cadmium poisoning:
  • • D. Chromium poisoning: Chromium exposure, particularly hexavalent chromium, can cause respiratory symptoms, skin ulcers, and an increased risk of cancer but does not lead to the vascular damage and gangrenous changes characteristic of Blackfoot disease caused by arsenic.
  • • D. Chromium poisoning:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blackfoot disease is a peripheral vascular disease caused by chronic exposure to high levels of arsenic, particularly in endemic regions where drinking water is contaminated. This condition results in severe ischemia and gangrene of the lower extremities, presenting as characteristic black discoloration and necrosis of the feet.

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management? ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)

questions.text: A rape victim is brought to the casualty of a government hospital for examination. Within what time should a vaginal swab be taken to look for the presence of spermatozoa? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Within 72 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms
  • ➤ Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms
  • ➤ •Spermatozoa remain motile in the vagina for 6-8 hours, occasionally up to 12 hours.
  • ➤ •Nonmotile forms can be detected for about 24 hours, rarely up to 48-72 hours.
  • ➤ •Detection involves aspirating vaginal contents and examining under a microscope.
  • ➤ •Motile sperms suggest recent intercourse; nonmotile sperms indicate a broader time frame (12-72 hours).
  • ➤ •Intact spermatozoa are rarely found in the vagina after 72 hours.
  • ➤ •Seminal fluid detection from vasectomized males requires prostatic acid phosphatase demonstration.
  • ➤ •P30, a semen-specific glycoprotein, is used as a screening test, detectable in vaginal fluid for about 27 hours.

questions.text: The term "St. Anthony's Fire" is historically associated with poisoning by which of the following substances? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • St. Anthony's Fire is an archaic term used to describe ergotism, a condition resulting from long-term poisoning with ergot alkaloids. These alkaloids are produced by the fungus Claviceps purpurea , which commonly infects rye and other grains. Ergotism is characterized by a range of symptoms, including vasoconstriction, hallucinations, and gangrene.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • b. Spanish fly: Spanish fly (cantharidin) is a toxic substance derived from blister beetles, causing severe irritation and blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. c. Crotalaria juncea: This plant contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which can cause liver damage and pulmonary hypertension. d. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxins are produced by certain molds and are potent carcinogens. They primarily affect the liver and can lead to liver cancer.
  • • b. Spanish fly: Spanish fly (cantharidin) is a toxic substance derived from blister beetles, causing severe irritation and blistering of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • • b. Spanish fly:
  • • c. Crotalaria juncea: This plant contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which can cause liver damage and pulmonary hypertension.
  • • c. Crotalaria juncea:
  • • d. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxins are produced by certain molds and are potent carcinogens. They primarily affect the liver and can lead to liver cancer.
  • • d. Aflatoxin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ St. Anthony's Fire is a historical term synonymous with ergotism, a condition caused by ergot alkaloid poisoning. Recognizing this association is important for understanding the historical context of this condition.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Suggillation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ Post Mortem Staining (PMS)
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin. Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.
  • ➤ It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • ➤ Other names of PMS are: Hypostasis livor mortis Vibices Suggillation Postmortem Lividity Cadaveric lividity Darkening of death

  • ➤ Vibices

  • ➤ Cadaveric lividity
  • ➤ Darkening of death
  • ➤ It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: What is bullet wipe? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.correct_answer: A. Residual from barrel of gun
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Residual from barrel of gun

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A "bullet wipe" is a gray or black ring around an entrance bullet hole. The ring is formed by bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal, and residue in the gun barrel from previous use. It is caused due to residue from barrel of the gun.
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option B) Blackening: It occurs due to combustion (smoke) produced by burning of gun powder when a firearm is fired.
  • • Option B) Blackening:
  • • Option C) Gutter fracture of skull: It occurs due to a bullet passing adjacent to the skull
  • • Option C) Gutter fracture of skull:
  • • Option D) Tattooing: It occurs due to unburnt gun powder particles which gets deposited around the firearm wound.
  • • Option D) Tattooing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)
  • ➤ Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)
  • ➤ • Black/gray ring around gunshot wound.
  • ➤ • Composition includes bullet lubrication, paraffin, lead, barrel debris, and gun oil.
  • ➤ • Wider side of the ring indicates the direction of fire.
  • ➤ • More noticeable in shots from freshly oiled weapons.
  • ➤ • It is dark in the center, fading towards the periphery.
  • ➤ • Prominent in clothing, termed as ‘bullet wipe.’
  • ➤ • It serve as proof of an entry wound in forensic analysis.

This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders. They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • ➤ They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department unconscious and without any identification. A non-contrast CT scan reveals hydrocephalus requiring immediate neurosurgical intervention to save the patient's life. Under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) can the neurosurgeon proceed with the surgery without obtaining informed consent? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Section 92 of the Indian Penal Code provides a legal framework for acting in good faith to save a person's life, even without their consent, when it is impossible to obtain consent and the action is intended to prevent death or grievous harm. In this scenario, the patient's altered mental state prevents them from providing informed consent, and the urgent nature of the hydrocephalus necessitates immediate intervention to save their life.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Section 87: This section deals with consent for acts not intended to cause death or grievous harm and is not applicable in this life-threatening situation. Section 89: This section concerns consent for children under 12 or individuals of unsound mind, requiring guardian consent, which is not feasible in this emergency. Section 90: This section defines when consent is invalid (e.g., given under fear or misconception), but it does not provide an exception for emergency situations.
  • • Section 87: This section deals with consent for acts not intended to cause death or grievous harm and is not applicable in this life-threatening situation.
  • • Section 87:
  • • Section 89: This section concerns consent for children under 12 or individuals of unsound mind, requiring guardian consent, which is not feasible in this emergency.
  • • Section 89:
  • • Section 90: This section defines when consent is invalid (e.g., given under fear or misconception), but it does not provide an exception for emergency situations.
  • • Section 90:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Section 92 of the IPC allows healthcare providers to act in good faith to save a person's life in emergencies where obtaining consent is impossible, provided the action is taken to prevent death or serious harm.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess. The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.
  • ➤ A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • ➤ The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found in a compromised position during a police raid, restrained in a manner that limits her ability to move her arms and legs independently, check the image shown below. The officers recognize this as a dangerous form of restraint that can severely restrict breathing and cause significant distress. What type of physical restraint is depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hog tying is a form of physical restraint where a person’s hands are tied behind their back, their feet are bound, and the hand and foot restraints are connected behind the back. This position severely restricts movement and can impair breathing, leading to positional asphyxia, which can be fatal. It is often considered a form of excessive force and has been associated with significant physical and psychological harm. Hog tying is also recognized as a method of torture due to its restrictive nature and the potential to cause severe distress and injury.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Four-point restraint: This restraint method involves securing both arms and legs to separate points, typically in a medical setting, such as a bed, to prevent self-harm or aggression. It does not involve coupling the hands and feet behind the back, making it less restrictive compared to hog tying.
  • • A. Four-point restraint:
  • • B. Chair restraint: Chair restraints secure an individual to a chair, immobilizing the arms, legs, and torso with straps. It provides control without the severe positional risks associated with hog tying.
  • • B. Chair restraint:
  • • D. Soft wrist and ankle restraints: These restraints are commonly used in clinical settings to prevent patients from harming themselves. They allow limited movement and do not involve the hazardous coupling of hands and feet behind the back.
  • • D. Soft wrist and ankle restraints:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hog tying is a hazardous restraint technique where hands and feet are bound together behind the back, posing severe risks such as positional asphyxia. It is recognized as a form of torture, similar to other inhumane methods like Wet submarino (suffocation in liquids), Dry submarino (plastic bag suffocation), Telefono (ear beating), Falanga (foot beating), Parrot’s perch (upside-down suspension), Planton (prolonged standing), Saw horse (sitting on sharp objects), Ghotna (rolling a log over legs), Chepuwa (log compression on legs), Black slave (hot metal rod in the anus), and Electric cattle prod (applying electric current to sensitive areas). These methods are extremely cruel and pose significant dangers to the victim.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma. Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.
  • • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.
  • • Option A. Vulval hematoma:
  • • Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.
  • • Option B. Condyloma acuminata:
  • • They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.
  • • Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.
  • • Option D. Bartholin cyst:
  • • It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 337,338
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 337,338

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her parents report that she is 15 weeks pregnant following a sexual assault. Ultrasound confirms the pregnancy and shows signs of fetal distress. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately inform the police and delay medical treatment until legal proceedings

options.label: B
options.text: Perform medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) with the consent of the girl and her parents under the supervision of a gynecologist

options.label: D
options.text: Offer information on adoption or foster care

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) with the consent of the girl and her parents under the supervision of a gynecologist
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In this case, the patient is a minor who is 15 weeks pregnant as a result of sexual assault and presents with severe symptoms and fetal distress . The first priority in this situation is the girl's health and safety , particularly given the distress and trauma.
  • • minor
  • • sexual assault
  • • severe symptoms and fetal distress
  • • first priority
  • • health and safety
  • • At 15 weeks gestation , medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is legally permissible with the informed consent of both the minor and her parents or legal guardians . Fetal distress further supports the need for prompt intervention to prevent complications. Till 20 weeks the termination can be performed by one trained Medical Officer or Gynecologist in a medically safe environment.
  • • 15 weeks gestation
  • • medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)
  • • informed consent
  • • parents or legal guardians
  • • trained Medical Officer or Gynecologist
  • • Reporting the sexual assault to the authorities is required by law but should not delay necessary medical treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Immediately inform the police and delay medical treatment until legal proceedings: While it is essential to report the sexual assault, delaying medical care in favor of legal proceedings is inappropriate. Medical treatment should not be postponed in an emergency situation, especially when the health of the patient is at risk.
  • • A. Immediately inform the police and delay medical treatment until legal proceedings:
  • • delaying medical care
  • • C. Provide emotional counseling and reassurance: Emotional support and counseling are important, but they are not substitutes for immediate medical intervention in the case of fetal distress and potential complications.
  • • C. Provide emotional counseling and reassurance:
  • • not substitutes for immediate medical intervention
  • • D. Offer information on adoption or foster care: Discussing adoption or foster care is not appropriate in this emergency situation . The focus should be on addressing the immediate medical needs of the patient.
  • • D. Offer information on adoption or foster care:
  • • emergency situation
  • • immediate medical needs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:
  • ➤ Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls. Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region, ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.
  • ➤ Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription.
  • ➤ Point mutations
  • ➤ Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls. Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  • ➤ Chromosomal translocations
  • ➤ Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region, ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.
  • ➤ Gene amplification
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no. 549-551
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Pg no. 549-551

questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Naloxone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.
  • • Option A. Fentanyl:
  • • Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.
  • • Option C. Morphine:
  • • Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.
  • • Option D. Bupivacaine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of Cajal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

  • ➤ Benedict' test - Reducing sugars.
  • ➤ Heat coagulation test - Proteins.
  • ➤ Rothera’s test – detect Ketone bodies in urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive with a bleeding wound on his abdomen, as shown below. The wound edges appear irregular and beveled, particularly on the opposite side of the wound. Based on the appearance and these specific characteristics, identify the type of wound shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a gunshot wound, which is characterized by several distinct features: a central round hole with surrounding soot soiling, burnt hairs (singeing), and punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles, known as tattooing. These findings are indicative of a close-range gunshot injury. Additionally, gunshot wounds may exhibit bevelling of edges, particularly at exit wounds, due to the outward force exerted by the bullet as it exits the body. The combination of soot deposition, singeing, and powder tattooing specifically points to a firearm injury, especially when the muzzle is close enough for these effects to be observed on the skin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Stab wound: Stab wounds present with sharp, clean edges and are usually slit-like or linear. They do not have the central round hole, soot soiling, singed hairs, or powder tattooing typical of gunshot wounds.
  • • A. Stab wound:
  • • B. Blunt force trauma: Blunt force trauma causes contusions, abrasions, and lacerations, without the distinctive central hole, soot, or burnt hair. These injuries are caused by blunt objects, not firearms.
  • • B. Blunt force trauma:
  • • D. Incised wound: Incised wounds are caused by sharp instruments, characterized by straight, clean edges and are usually longer than they are deep. They lack the features of soot, singeing, and tattooing seen in gunshot wounds.
  • • D. Incised wound:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gunshot wounds can be identified by a central round hole, surrounding soot soiling, singed hairs, punctate lesions from powder particles, and bevelling of wound edges in exit wounds. Recognizing these features is essential for distinguishing gunshot injuries from other types of trauma in clinical and forensic settings.

questions.text: What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023) Pulmonary Aortic Mitral
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eosin B is not a component of the Papanicolaou stain, which uses a combination of hematoxylin, Orange G, and Eosin Azure (including Eosin Y and Light Green SF) to differentially stain cellular components.

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule

options.label: B
options.text: All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

options.label: C
options.text: Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase

options.label: D
options.text: Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.correct_answer: B. All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines under the National Immunization Schedule can be safely administered, while live vaccines should be given with caution depending on the child's immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. The patient complaints that his stools emit a faint glow and release mild fumes. The patient reports consuming various food items at a local festival recently. Based on the luminescent nature of the stools (aka Smoky stool syndrome) and the clinical presentation, which substance is most likely responsible for the toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acute phosphorus poisoning is characterized by luminescent stools, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. The luminescent nature of the stools is due to the phosphorescent properties of phosphorus, which can also produce mild fumes, known as "smoky stool syndrome." This unique feature is a hallmark of phosphorus poisoning, often seen when the substance is ingested, either accidentally or intentionally. Phosphorus is commonly found in certain pesticides and fireworks, making exposure possible in various settings, such as festivals.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and a garlic-like odor on the breath. Stools in arsenic poisoning are usually greenish or blackish but do not exhibit luminescence.
  • • A. Arsenic:
  • • C. Iron: Iron toxicity leads to symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and black or dark green stools due to iron sulfide formation. However, iron poisoning does not cause luminescent stools or the smoky stool syndrome observed with phosphorus poisoning.
  • • C. Iron:
  • • D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with abdominal pain, headache, constipation, and a bluish line on the gums. Stools are generally dark or tarry but do not glow or emit fumes as seen in phosphorus poisoning.
  • • D. Lead:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphorus poisoning is distinct due to its characteristic luminescent stools, often accompanied by abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. The luminescence and mild fume release, referred to as "smoky stool syndrome," differentiate it from other toxicities. Other poisoning symptoms include garlic-like breath in arsenic, bluish gum lines in lead, pinpoint pupils in organophosphates, and cherry-red skin in carbon monoxide. Recognizing these signs is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and treatment in toxicological emergencies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

options.label: B
options.text: If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done

options.label: D
options.text: Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.correct_answer: A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.
